summary: Email correspondence between a partner at Boies Schiller Flexner LLP and an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York regarding a witness's journal entries. The attorney is providing photographs of journal pages that reference the witness's experiences with Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, specifically entries from December 1995 and January 1996 detailing a trip to Epstein's house and going to the movies with him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of the witness's journal entries describing going to his house and to the movies with him in 1996.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Epstein as part of the witness's experiences that are the subject of the investigation.

connections.description: Both are referenced together as the subjects of the witness's experiences and the investigation.

events.title: First Journal Entry
events.description: A journal entry from December 1995, described as the shortest and hardest to read, written in fading colored pencil.

events.title: NY Trip to Epstein's House
events.description: Journal entry describing the highlights of a New York trip and going to Jeffrey Epstein's house.

events.title: Movies with Epstein
events.description: Journal entry describing going to the movies with Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
401 E. Las Olas Blvd., Suite 1200, Fort Lauderdale, FL, 33301
keyFacts: A witness's personal journal entries from 1995-1996 were being provided to the U.S. Attorney's Office to assist in the investigation of Epstein and Maxwell.
The journal entries specifically describe the witness going to Jeffrey Epstein's house and to the movies with him in January 1996.
The correspondence is between a law firm partner (Boies Schiller Flexner LLP) and an Assistant U.S. Attorney, indicating legal cooperation in the investigation.
The journal was used by the witness to refresh her recollection during an interview with investigators.
The emails demonstrate an ongoing evidence-gathering process by the Southern District of New York in early 2020.
